pros: Indiana University Foundation has a great mission and a wonderful work environment. They really understand that you have a life outside of work -- there is a desire to do great work, but not at the expense of your personal life. They have really great time off policies and go out of their way to recognize their employees with holiday parties, annual holiday gifts, and the like. They support career advancement and do a great job of providing the training you need to do your job well. There is also a push for involvement with professional organizations to further your education and training.
cons: While the pay is good, there are generally limited opportunities for raises, aside from changing jobs. This is less than ideal, but it is certainly the norm at most nonprofits. There isn't a lot of turnover at the Foundation, which can lead to some folks staying with the organization for many, many years. This inhibits the growth of new ideas and fresh perspectives, but it also creates an institutional legacy that can be helpful in a fundraising environment -- potential donors develop strong connections with people who have worked at the Foundation for many, many years. Also, the old age of the database system they use may be problematic for some. It is a workable program, but it is in dire need of updating, which senior management seems reluctant to invest in.

pros: It's more or less a typical 8-5 office job, but the people are nice, the management is very good, the facility is in good shape, and they treat their employees well.  They also like to promote from within the company, so there can be the potential for some advancement opportunities if you play your cards right.  IU Foundation also has a very warm and welcoming company culture, and I haven't witnessed any of the ugly office politics that you tend to see in some corporate office environments.  Judging from my experience, if you work hard and do a good job, then you'll be treated well and appreciated.  One couldn't ask for a whole lot more.
cons: I really don't have too many complaints.  I suppose the pay could be a little better, but let's face it:  you're not going to get rich working at a non-profit organization.  Also, things tend to move a little slowly sometimes, but there's a big difference between moving slowly and not at all.  Progress is progress, even if it does sometimes take a little longer than it should.

pros: Great managers, coworkers, and Execs.  The communication is better here than anywhere else I have worked (and I have been working for 50 years).  There is a team spirit and general belief in helping each other toward a goal of providing excellent service.  It is truly a team environment.  There is available training, also health benefits as stated in other reviews, very good compensation package overall, clean atmosphere, nice workstations, great IT staff for support, occasional activity meetings with food provided.
cons: I have the perfect job assignment, but I am nearing the end of my career.  If you are young and looking for quick promotions, this might be difficult here.  Namely, because it is so nice here and benefits and pay are good, that there is very little turnover.  So, higher job availability is slow to come.  But IUF offers great experience and can lead you to other jobs at IU if you are in need of faster promotions.

pros: The work environment is very friendly.  My workstation accommodations are kept very clean and tasteful refreshments are provided in the break room. pros:
The people at IUF are wonderful and generally supportive of one another, especially during busy times of the school year.
If you are part of a cross-functional team or office, you gain valuable insight into and knowledge of fundraising, project management, team leadership, and nonprofit processes.
Benefits were amazing and the best in the area. Employees also could create their own after-work groups to get to know one another, with goals ranging from being more active to discussing eco-friendly practices to enjoying conversation over after-hours drinks or dinner. There was a very high level of camaraderie that I really miss!
cons:
Pay was a bit low, and opportunities for growth were somewhat stunted.
Some departments worked in silos, so communicating across departments was sometimes difficult if the left hand didn't know what the right was doing.
Senior leaders were often seen as sitting in an ivory tower, rather than down on the ground floor with their employees. Many of my peers felt there was a disconnect between upper managment and the people who kept things in motion day by day.
IUF is very much an extroverted organization with many strong personalities among its staff. It was difficult to navigate that landscape, even as an ambivert!
